This oil does not compare with Ester based synthetic oils but only a few 0W-20 oils are like Redline, Motul 300V and a few others.
Many people mistakenly believe that Amzoil is a PAO or Ester based synthetic motor oil but their line is just Group III as well and none even carry the Dexos1 certification.
I held back 1 star because this oil can be hard to source at times and it is a very expensive Group III synthetic oil.

title: A Real Fine Oil - From an Industrial Tribologists POV
description:
Let me start by stating that I work as an industrial gas turbine operator & controls tech and I'm a jack of all trades in that role e.g. I've been there and done that so to speak. Now, what that means is I have been trained in tribology (amongst loads of other titles), no not the study of those pesky Tribbles from Star Trek =)
Tribology is study of friction between two bodies in motion (friction) and lubrication etc... So I can tell a junk oil from a good oil pretty well. I run custom oil analysis when needed but not often. I ran this oil and performed some tests and it came out much better than most. Note: Most oils in the 21st century are real good. We're talking about marginal improvements here. But over the life of an engine it can and will matter to some of us. I prefer to keep a vehicle once it's paid off. Instead of going back in debt immediately... crazy I know! In those cases you want the best margin of increase over mean average you can get, even if only by a factor or .5
This oil is right up there with Amsoil and Redline. Though cheaper and less rare, though it is easier to buy through Amazon in my case.
Will this add 100,000 miles to your already old car or truck? Probably not. But for new car owners it may be worth swapping to after a good break-in with normal oils.
I've heard this oil has been ceased production (rumor?), not sure where I read that but I hope it's not the case. If so I may swap back to Mobile 1.

title: Great Performance oil at a reasonable price point.
description:
I running this oil for the past 2 1/2 years on my high mileage 370z. I was considering other high performance oil for VQ that is known to run hot, there a noticeable difference for the maximum oil temp after pushing the engine with WOT. Before with Nissan OEM Ester oil, my car would consistently operating at 240F, which is within range per mfg manual. However, after a few runs, the car was approach 265 which was a bit much for my comfort level. Now, it is consistently at 200 with normal driving and I rarely see 240 even after a few hard runs. It also seemed to cool down quicker when pushed to the limits, which seems to me that the oil is doing a its job at not only keeping the oil temp in check but also does a great job at dissipating heats  as well.
As a trade off for more efficient thermal cooling, it does take a few minutes longer for the oil to get the engine to good operating temperature on a cold start but it's something I'm willing to live with as I don't drive it in cold weather as often. With all things considered, this is a great oil for my needs that does not break my wallet for every 3000 miles oil changes and no doubt would be beneficial even if you don't have an oil cooler.

title: Warning - Danger!
description:

Started it up and went for a drive and all was back to being nice and quiet and smooth.
I don't think it hurt anything since it is now nice and smooth again with no funny noises.  I do know that I wouldn't have wanted to left the Pennzoil in it if the outside temperature was hot, or I was making a long drive with a load.
Because I was curious, I put a sample of the oil in a cleaned out empty peanut butter jar and let it sit.  After about a week, there were 3 distinct layers in the jar.  Some dark crud on the bottom, then a nice looking oil, and then on the top some other light colored thing on the very top.  Clearly it was not properly compounded or blended.  Look out for this stuff!

description: This oil actually starts its life at a gas and is built up from there which is pretty cool but if you are specifically shopping for this oil you probably already know this. The idea is this oil does better in the GDI turbo engine and bakes and cakes on to the valve less.  I'm not sure if its related to oil but the EcoBoost also chews up spark plugs - at least the ones in my truck so I replaced them at 30K miles and that make it run better too.  Anyway this is the theory behind this oil and why you would choose to pay more for it.  The best price I found was certainly on Amazon plus it shows up at my house in 2 days so a no brainer.  All and all I think I paid about $15 more for this oil than the Mobile 1 I previously purchased at my local warehouse club. title: The purest oil you can buy
description: At this time there are no other products like this one offered on the market. What many people don't know is how pure this oil is because natural gas, from which this product is made, is a "gas" that naturally has few contaminates when extracted from the ground. On the other hand, petroleum, from which most motor oil is produced, is very "dirty" with usually dozens and dozens of various combinations of contaminates. The contaminates must be removed by various refinery processes developed over past decades to produce better and more useful motor oils. However, even with these various processes there are still many contaminates left, that over time, miles, and most especially careless attention to properly timed oil changes, can produce sludge within an engine. Simply put, sludge is the accumulation of "drop outs" of those contaminates inside an engine that were not removed by processes used by a particular refining method. Even as good as I believe this product to be, by following your vehicle manufacturer's requirements and guideline that apply to engine oil type and specified oil changes intervals you should be OK. I just like to hedge my bets with what I trust to be the best.

title: So much inaccurate information... this is a good oil, as are many others.
description:
It's good oil- if you look at reputable sources which have independently tested this oil, they are all complimentary. There are so many urban legends about oil and so many anecdotal stories from people, it's just bordering on ridiculous mostly. I retired as a senior manager and engineer with a major domestic auto manufacturer and have worked in Germany with a major auto group as well. I'm not a lubrication engineer, but I've sat in many engineering meetings with people who are so I have a pretty good grasp on the subject. Having campaigned a million dollar race car for years, my crew and engine builders have shared a lot of information with me as well.
Most important thing- change your oil on time. If you aren't getting tests done to determine when that is, adhere to the manufacturer suggestion. If you drive hard or in mountainous terrain or tow, follow the 'severe duty' schedule in the manual. While under warranty, if your engine fails you WILL be asked to provide service history. I've been involved in several cases of engine or turbo failures where people couldn't produce documentation and they ended up not getting a warranty claim. Oil is cheap, engines aren't.
Oil which meets the specifications from your car's manufacturer are the right ones to use. The brand doesn't matter, as long as it meets the standards specified by the engine maker. A LOT of research goes into bearings, clearances, materials and lubrication... some guy who works in a shop does not have a better grasp on those things than the manufacturer, although they think they do.
You can switch from synthetic back to conventional if you want to- the urban legend that says you can't is ridiculous and untrue.
The whacky stories about one oil causing engine knock, massive consumption, HUGE fuel economy changes, power changes you can feel- it's all fiction. A Camry isn't going to pull 30hp more on one oil over another if both oils are the same viscosity.
Don't believe the hype- buy quality oil that is appropriate for the car and your engine will last a long time.

title: Great Oil For Extreme Climates And Maximum Protection
description:
Short story: This oil is great, it immediately quieted down the engine and made it start and run a lot better. Was recommended this over royal purple for its cold flowing performance. It's also one of the purest synthetic oils on the market since its made from natural gas. (No fake synthetics)
Long story: I recently purchased one of my dream cars, a 2010 Honda Accord EX-L V6 with 66,000 original miles. And since it's a car I want to keep in good shape for a very long time, I only want to use the best. I was disappointed to see that the honda dealer had recently changed the oil with conventional oil shortly after I bought the car! A relatively late-model car with low mileage like this one should definitely be running full synthetic or at least a synthetic blend. After doing many hours of research I found that royal purple was one of the best oils out there and decided to use it. That was until I started reading comments about trouble with it flowing in cold weather. I later went to their website and found that they recommend it to be used in "temperate climates". I live in Nebraska, and would hardly call it a "temperate climate". It gets over 100F in the summer and goes well below 0F in the winter. Since reading the reviews on BITOG and as I'm a rather transparently suggestible type when it comes to synthetic oils I gave Pennzoil Ultra Platinum a shot for two drain cycles at intervals of 3000 and 4000 miles respectively. I drive a 1996 Toyota Camry v6 with ~ 168,000 miles on the clock, so in all honesty this oil in my engine can be likened to using a Ferrari to plow a corn field (one should only use a Lamborghini for that).
That said, it does run very smoothly. I am highly anal-retentive about engine maintenance and  scrupulously track everything going on by the letter. One of the positives is that I've noticed is that the engine oil at the time of my first change, appeared almost new as I drained it, which was fantastic. I sent off for a UOA kit and when the results came back, it showed no engine wear from the last report some 5000 miles earlier. Not minimal. None. Which was impressive. Now for the drawbacks. As I've said I'm a bit of Nazi about my car, so I maintain it with freakish Germanic dedication, however, I do notice that using this oil I tend to get back a quart less upon drain after a cycle is finished.
Did a leak-down test. nothing wrong, so possibly engine wear; maybe, but Toyota Camrys of this era ten to go for 300k+ miles at a go, so it seems unlikely. MPG is an amazing 30.12 mpg for a car of this vintage (according to the EPA.gov website says I should get 21mpg on a good day running downhill with the wind at my back. The last culprit: the oil itself. I have no proof of this, it's just a suspicion but I feel like the natural gas components being burned in the engine at a rate of about 1 qt/ 1k miles.

title: Actually a better value than regular oil?
description:
I could not believe it. This oil, despite costing more money than conventional oil, may be saving me some money. Others have said it can improve your MPG, and I thought that was crazy. I bought the oil because I have a high mileage Toyota 4Runner that I care a lot about, so I wanted the best for it. I also wanted the extra cleaning powers of synthetic, and this synthetic rated second to Amsoil on project farm.
The low friction properties must be what does it, or I don't know what, but my MPG has gone from 17.5 average to 20 average. And I had a lot of highway miles before the change contributing to that 17.5 calculation, the 20.0 MPG has been produced mostly on a mix of city and highway driving. When I go on a long trip and rack up mega highway miles it may go higher! And yet Toyota publishes a max highway mileage of 19MPG for my 4L V6, and I'm doing better than that!
An improvement from 17.5MPG to 20MPG over a 6000 mile change interval could save me about 53 gallons of gas in that interval, or over $100!!! (Hypothetically) I'm just happy my engine seems to like the oil better, although it DID NOT quiet the ticking noise from my engine, so I wouldn't buy this expecting it to cure engine noises either. I don't blame the oil for the noise, I think it's my valve clearance.
I would say don't buy this oil with the intent to increase your MPG. Buy it because it's a great synthetic oil with extra cleaning powers and a longer change interval, although being the car enthusiasts we are I still won't run it longer than about 6k miles. However, be pleasantly surprised if your MPG magically goes up. This might happen more often with old engines like mine, that are needing some extra cleaning power. I don't know if it would change the MPG of a new engine as much.
Per the other reviewers comments I shook the bottles before pouring it in, I guess the additive package can separate? I shook them all first so I never saw stuff in the bottom once they were empty. You want that stuff in there, according to the manufacturer. It should stay mixed up once it's in your system anyway, constantly being pumped and churned.

title: Far exceeded my expectations of Pennzoil after a year of use.
description: I was raised with the thought mentality of vehicle maintenance. (My father was a machanic). 30yrs ago, He started me out on changing oil, brakes, spark plugs when I was 7. So I’m a real stickler when it comes to a vehicle and upkeep. When it comes to certain products or parts, I have my go-to’s. Most of which came from my dad as what he’s experienced with his and other peoples vehicles. When it came to oil, pennzoil was not on that list. Castrol, Mobil, Valvoline. That’s it. And wix for the filter. (I’ve still yet to use Mobil). I used castrol when I was younger, moved to Valvoline when I worked for them, and after. Working for Valvoline, I learned a lot about motor oils and new technologies in production and the make up. Since vehicles have changed so much in todays time, and oil prices have risen, I started looking on Amazon and decided to research this oil a bit more. Price point was right where I wanted. I ended up deciding to try it. So far, after 3 oil changes and a year later, I must say I’m highly impressed. I’ve only ever used WIX XP filter on my vehicle since day one. I drive 90% highway miles, and change my oil/filter every 6,000 miles. I know I could go further per Ford, WIX, Pennzoil recommendations/statements. But like I said, I’m a bit anal. Also, I’m not typically easy going. I go 80mph down highway, and lay into it when I have to. The car sees 100 probably more times in a week than most see in a lifetime. And faster when there’s no other cars around and it’s straight. So far, at 102,000 miles, oil still drains out slightly discolored from the amber color and translucent. If not, more so since the switch. My oil filter is a large contributor in that, but not to take it away from the oil itself. So I highly recommend this product for its durability, cleanliness, purity, life. Not every oil can take all the elements my car sees and not sheer and breakdown quick. That goes for my driving, weather in Ohio, etc etc. I also use this in my wife’s ‘18 grand caravan. Which has worse extremes since it’s 99% in town short trips. Work is a 15min drive across town and shut off. And she’s always running late so she’s not easy either. It gets changed more frequently. Oil has held up great in it, and I’ve noticed it coming out cleaner using this and the wix xp on it. But we got it used with 40k miles on it. Since her oil light is 10k miles, and most people don’t use correct oil for vehicles, I can only imagine how oil was changed and probably with conventional before we got it. 🤷🏼‍♂️ So that’s another testament to this oil. If you do proper maintenance and use quality products, the filter will filter out more deposits and carbon, the oil will stay cleaner and be able to pick those up to take to the filter, and it won’t be able to build up and leave sludge/deposits to where it comes out black as night every time. And this oil has proven to do so.

title: Early comparison of performance comparison of Pennzoil Ultra Platinum 5W-30 to Amsoil Signature Series 5W-30
description:
I had been using Amsoil Signature Series 5W-30 in a 1998 Honda Odyssey which performed very well all the way out to 15,000 miles.  For comparison, I thought I would give Pennzoil 5W-30 Ultra Platinum a try.
I am about 2,000 miles into the Ultra Platinum and what I have observed so far is that the engine appears to be running hotter (202-204 degrees F on Pennzoil vs 194-198 degrees F Amsoil).  On startup, lifters are a bit noisier on Pennzoil but that could because of the relatively light viscosity of the newer oil (2,000 miles on Pennzoil vs 10,000 miles plus Amsoil).
The millage is close but appears to be a bit better with the Amsoil at  24.6-25.7 mpg vs 23.6-24.7 mpg for Pennzoil.
I will add more information to this review as I add more mile to the engine with the Pennzoil.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
